results.title: Forces make forms
results.creator_credit: Kinex productions, FilmFair Communications, Harry Robin and Peter Wright
results.brief_description: Unusual and everyday objects and events are used to encourage critical observation and logical association between forces in operation and their resultant forms. Examples of both natural and man-made forces and the forms they create are designed to assist students to become aware of their visual environment. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Force of evil
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Enterprise Studios, Bob Roberts and Abraham Polonsky
results.brief_description: John Garfield gives one of his most outstanding performances as the successful Wall Street lawyer Joe Morse who has made his considerable fortune out of petty corruption and looking after the interests of the gambling underworld. When big-time racketeer Ben Tucker (Roy Roberts) gets Joe to assist him in controlling the New York numbers game, Joe has to put the career and life of his own brother, Leo (Thomas Gomez), in jeopardy. This forces Joe into having to decide between the seduction of big money and loyalty to his brother. From this minimalist film-noir plot, Polonsky has fashioned a dark fable about the American Dream. Notable also for being one of the first Hollywood films to use location street shots, the imposing skyscrapers and the depressing tenement slums of New York City add layers of visual meaning to the film, further drawing connections between good and evil, morality and criminality, poverty and wealth. Polonsky’s and Garfield’s careers were to be destroyed by the McCarthy political witch-hunts, particularly when they refused to betray their friends in the show-trials for the House of Un-American Activities. “Force of Evil”, and it’s critical examination of wealth and power in urban America was used as evidence of their Communist leanings. The film is based on the novel “Tucker’s People” by Ira Wolfert.

results.title: Force & motion: Newton's 3 Laws
results.creator_credit: Barr Films and P. David Langley
results.brief_description: Using experiments and laboratory demonstrations, this basic physics film clearly explains Newton’s three fundamental laws of force and motion: the velocity of an object remains constant unless a force acts upon the object; Force=Mass * Acceleration; and to every action there is an equal and opposite reaction.

results.title: Forbidden marriages in the Holy Land [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Sindibad Films, Sourat Films, Jerusalem Film Institute, Peace Media Programme of the European Union and Michel Khleifi
results.brief_description: This is a portrayal of the various kinds of mixed marriages ranging across different generations and social classes between the Arabs and Jews of Palestine/Israel and how the couples involved have dealt with the difficult problems that confront them in today’s tense environment. Not only is there the complication of Jew marrying Arab, but religion, whether it be Islam, Christian or Judaism plays a central role in all their lives. For example, it is forbidden for Muslim women to marry Jewish men, but a Muslim man is allowed to marry a Jewish woman if she converts to Islam. In Judaism it is forbidden to marry outside the religion, Christians are against mixed marriages and Islam although condoning marriage by Muslim men with Jews or Christians do not condone marriage with Buddhists, Hindus or atheists. All the couples interviewed in this documentary have gone against the social, political and religious norms but in their personal narratives we see the human side of the Arab-Israeli conflict, the pain of being ex-communicated from unaccepting family and friends, of children growing up not knowing their grandparents, and of bitter prejudices of religious and racial intolerances. But the over-riding factor is the love and respect for each other and each other’s culture and religion. Along with the couples’ stories we are also given an insight to the religious point of view through leaders from each of the respective faiths, Islam, Christian and Judaism. Director, Michel Khleifi, through this film points out the urgent need for the Middle East to bring in a civil code of marriage which will liberate the individual from all religious constraints, from the three monotheistic faiths, and allow a freedom of choice. In Arabic and Hebrew with English subtitles.

results.title: Forbidden city: the great within
results.creator_credit: Discovery Channel, Maroon Production, Totem Films and Mick Kaczorowski
results.brief_description: The Emperors of China conquered the world and then locked it out. Cinematographer, Zhao Fei, takes his cameras into the inner sanctums of the Forbidden City, to explore the private world of emperors, concubines and eunuchs, who lived in palaces with lavish gardens and temples. Re-creations based on Imperial archives and rare manuscripts create a fascinating portrait of a way of life and tradition hidden for hundreds of years. Narrated by Rod Steiger.

results.title: Forage harvesting
results.brief_description: This film presents a demonstration of labor-saving machines and methods for harvesting forage crops. Greater accent on mixed farming in Canada has increased the need for winter silage and, in the busy harvest season, for more efficient ways of cutting, handling and storing forage crops. We are shown the use of such equipment as the forage harvester and the automatic unloader, which greatly reduces the amount of work and time involved.

results.title: For Your Tomorrow
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Graham Parker and Robert Wylam
results.brief_description: Made to commemorate the 60th anniversary of the end of World War 1, this film traces events leading to the declaration of war, and eventually to Canada’s involvement, when, on August 3, 1914, Great Britain and the Empire declared their support of their allies. This film uses both archival and new footage which reveals the contributions and sacrifices of those Canadians who served in World War 1.

results.title: For you, Mr. Bell
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, William Canning and George Pearson
results.brief_description: This film profile of Alexander Graham Bell, inventor of the telephone and pioneer in many other fields of technology, including heavier-than-air flight, is a warmly human story. Full of anecdotes, it tells the story of a man whose main concern was finding a way to alleviate the problems of the deaf. It is told largely through photographs of Bell, of his wife who was deaf, of their spacious retreat at Baddeck, Nova Scotia, and of people who shared in his work and experiments. Written by Strowan Robertson, photography by David de Volpi.

results.title: For you madam. [No. 70/12] = Pour vous madame
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine item on French perfumes. Shows the travels of perfume from Gras to Paris. First the flowers are picked, the essential oils pressed out then distilling in a warehouse. In the laboratory these are mixed by “the hose”. We then see bottles being bvlown ready for the perfume. Each designer has a perfume and we see the dress and the finished bottle. However it takes 160 people to produce 9,000 bottles a day. Designers appearing on film include Dior, Givenchy, Guy La Roche, Chanel etc.
